Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

class model.dim3.nnformer.ContiguousGrad(*args, **kwargs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_out)[source]ÔÉÅ

Defines a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation (alias to the vjp function).

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses.

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computated w.r.t. the output.

static forward(ctx, x)[source]ÔÉÅ

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. There are two ways to define forward:

Usage 1 (Combined forward and ctx):

@staticmethod
def forward(ctx: Any, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> Any:
    pass

  • It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by any number of arguments (tensors or other types).

  • See combining-forward-context for more details

Usage 2 (Separate forward and ctx):

@staticmethod
def forward(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> Any:
    pass

@staticmethod
def setup_context(ctx: Any, inputs: Tuple[Any, ...], output: Any) -> None:
    pass

  • The forward no longer accepts a ctx argument.

  • Instead, you must also override the torch.autograd.Function.setup_context() staticmethod to handle setting up the ctx object. output is the output of the forward, inputs are a Tuple of inputs to the forward.

  • See extending-autograd for more details

The context can be used to store arbitrary data that can be then retrieved during the backward pass. Tensors should not be stored directly on ctx (though this is not currently enforced for backward compatibility). Instead, tensors should be saved either with ctx.save_for_backward() if they are intended to be used in backward (equivalently, vjp) or ctx.save_for_forward() if they are intended to be used for in jvp.

class model.dim3.nnformer_utils.SegmentationNetwork[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: NeuralNetwork

predict_2D(x, do_mirroring: bool, mirror_axes: tuple = (0, 1, 2), use_sliding_window: bool = False, step_size: float = 0.5, patch_size: tuple | None = None, regions_class_order: tuple | None = None, use_gaussian: bool = False, pad_border_mode: str = 'constant', pad_kwargs: dict | None = None, all_in_gpu: bool = False, verbose: bool = True, mixed_precision: bool = True) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

Use this function to predict a 2D image. If this is a 3D U-Net it will crash because you cannot predict a 2D image with that (you dummy). When running predictions, you need to specify whether you want to run fully convolutional of sliding window based inference. We very strongly recommend you use sliding window with the default settings. It is the responsibility of the user to make sure the network is in the proper mode (eval for inference!). If the network is not in eval mode it will print a warning. :param x: Your input data. Must be a nd.ndarray of shape (c, x, y). :param do_mirroring: If True, use test time data augmentation in the form of mirroring :param mirror_axes: Determines which axes to use for mirroing. Per default, mirroring is done along all three axes :param use_sliding_window: if True, run sliding window prediction. Heavily recommended! This is also the default :param step_size: When running sliding window prediction, the step size determines the distance between adjacent predictions. The smaller the step size, the denser the predictions (and the longer it takes!). Step size is given as a fraction of the patch_size. 0.5 is the default and means that wen advance by patch_size * 0.5 between predictions. step_size cannot be larger than 1! :param patch_size: The patch size that was used for training the network. Do not use different patch sizes here, this will either crash or give potentially less accurate segmentations :param regions_class_order: Fabian only :param use_gaussian: (Only applies to sliding window prediction) If True, uses a Gaussian importance weighting

to weigh predictions closer to the center of the current patch higher than those at the borders. The reason behind this is that the segmentation accuracy decreases towards the borders. Default (and recommended): True

Parameters:

  • pad_border_mode ‚Äì leave this alone

  • pad_kwargs ‚Äì leave this alone

  • all_in_gpu ‚Äì experimental. You probably want to leave this as is it

  • verbose ‚Äì Do you want a wall of text? If yes then set this to True

Returns:

predict_3D(x: ndarray, do_mirroring: bool, mirror_axes: Tuple[int, ...] = (0, 1, 2), use_sliding_window: bool = False, step_size: float = 0.5, patch_size: Tuple[int, ...] | None = None, regions_class_order: Tuple[int, ...] | None = None, use_gaussian: bool = False, pad_border_mode: str = 'constant', pad_kwargs: dict | None = None, all_in_gpu: bool = False, verbose: bool = True, mixed_precision: bool = True) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

Use this function to predict a 3D image. It does not matter whether the network is a 2D or 3D U-Net, it will detect that automatically and run the appropriate code. When running predictions, you need to specify whether you want to run fully convolutional of sliding window based inference. We very strongly recommend you use sliding window with the default settings. It is the responsibility of the user to make sure the network is in the proper mode (eval for inference!). If the network is not in eval mode it will print a warning. :param x: Your input data. Must be a nd.ndarray of shape (c, x, y, z). :param do_mirroring: If True, use test time data augmentation in the form of mirroring :param mirror_axes: Determines which axes to use for mirroing. Per default, mirroring is done along all three axes :param use_sliding_window: if True, run sliding window prediction. Heavily recommended! This is also the default :param step_size: When running sliding window prediction, the step size determines the distance between adjacent predictions. The smaller the step size, the denser the predictions (and the longer it takes!). Step size is given as a fraction of the patch_size. 0.5 is the default and means that wen advance by patch_size * 0.5 between predictions. step_size cannot be larger than 1! :param patch_size: The patch size that was used for training the network. Do not use different patch sizes here, this will either crash or give potentially less accurate segmentations :param regions_class_order: Fabian only :param use_gaussian: (Only applies to sliding window prediction) If True, uses a Gaussian importance weighting

to weigh predictions closer to the center of the current patch higher than those at the borders. The reason behind this is that the segmentation accuracy decreases towards the borders. Default (and recommended): True

Parameters:

  • pad_border_mode ‚Äì leave this alone

  • pad_kwargs ‚Äì leave this alone

  • all_in_gpu ‚Äì experimental. You probably want to leave this as is it

  • verbose ‚Äì Do you want a wall of text? If yes then set this to True

  • mixed_precision ‚Äì if True, will run inference in mixed precision with autocast()

Returns:

predict_3D_pseudo3D_2Dconv(x: ndarray, min_size: Tuple[int, int], do_mirroring: bool, mirror_axes: tuple = (0, 1), regions_class_order: tuple | None = None, pseudo3D_slices: int = 5, all_in_gpu: bool = False, pad_border_mode: str = 'constant', pad_kwargs: dict | None = None, verbose: bool = True) → Tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]ÔÉÅ

class model.dim3.trans_layers.LayerNorm(normalized_shape, eps=1e-05, data_format='channels_first')[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: Module

LayerNorm that supports two data formats: channels_last (default) or channels_first. The ordering of the dimensions in the inputs. channels_last corresponds to inputs with shape (batch_size, height, width, channels) while channels_first corresponds to inputs with shape (batch_size, channels, height, width).

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

class model.dim3.vtunet_utils.BasicLayer(dim, depth, depths, num_heads, window_size=(1, 7, 7), mlp_ratio=4.0, qkv_bias=False, qk_scale=None, drop=0.0, attn_drop=0.0, drop_path=0.0, drop_path_rate=0.0, norm_layer=<class 'torch.nn.modules.normalization.LayerNorm'>, downsample=None, use_checkpoint=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: Module

A basic Swin Transformer layer for one stage.

Parameters:

  • dim (int) ‚Äì Number of feature channels

  • depth (int) ‚Äì Depths of this stage.

  • num_heads (int) ‚Äì Number of attention head.

  • window_size (tuple[int]) ‚Äì Local window size. Default: (1,7,7).

  • mlp_ratio (float) ‚Äì Ratio of mlp hidden dim to embedding dim. Default: 4.

  • qkv_bias (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, add a learnable bias to query, key, value. Default: True

  • qk_scale (float | None, optional) ‚Äì Override default qk scale of head_dim ** -0.5 if set.

  • drop (float, optional) ‚Äì Dropout rate. Default: 0.0

  • attn_drop (float, optional) ‚Äì Attention dropout rate. Default: 0.0

  • drop_path (float | tuple[float], optional) ‚Äì Stochastic depth rate. Default: 0.0

  • norm_layer (nn.Module, optional) ‚Äì Normalization layer. Default: nn.LayerNorm

  • downsample (nn.Module | None, optional) ‚Äì Downsample layer at the end of the layer. Default: None

Bases: Module

A basic Swin Transformer layer for one stage.

Parameters:

  • dim (int) ‚Äì Number of input channels.

  • input_resolution (tuple[int]) ‚Äì Input resolution.

  • depth (int) ‚Äì Number of blocks.

  • num_heads (int) ‚Äì Number of attention heads.

  • tuple (window_size) ‚Äì Local window size.

  • mlp_ratio (float) ‚Äì Ratio of mlp hidden dim to embedding dim.

  • qkv_bias (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, add a learnable bias to query, key, value. Default: True

  • qk_scale (float | None, optional) ‚Äì Override default qk scale of head_dim ** -0.5 if set.

  • drop (float, optional) ‚Äì Dropout rate. Default: 0.0

  • attn_drop (float, optional) ‚Äì Attention dropout rate. Default: 0.0

  • drop_path (float | tuple[float], optional) ‚Äì Stochastic depth rate. Default: 0.0

  • norm_layer (nn.Module, optional) ‚Äì Normalization layer. Default: nn.LayerNorm

  • downsample (nn.Module | None, optional) ‚Äì Downsample layer at the end of the layer. Default: None

  • use_checkpoint (bool) ‚Äì Whether to use checkpointing to save memory. Default: False.

class model.dim3.vtunet_utils.SwinTransformerSys3D(pretrained=None, pretrained2d=True, img_size=(128, 128, 128), patch_size=(4, 4, 4), in_chans=4, num_classes=3, embed_dim=96, depths=[2, 2, 2, 1], depths_decoder=[1, 2, 2, 2], num_heads=[3, 6, 12, 24], window_size=(7, 7, 7), mlp_ratio=4.0, qkv_bias=True, qk_scale=None, drop_rate=0.0, attn_drop_rate=0.0, drop_path_rate=0.1, norm_layer=<class 'torch.nn.modules.normalization.LayerNorm'>, patch_norm=True, use_checkpoint=False, frozen_stages=-1, final_upsample='expand_first', **kwargs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: Module

Swin Transformer

A PyTorch impl of : Swin Transformer: Hierarchical Vision Transformer using Shifted Windows -

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2103.14030

Parameters:

  • img_size (int | tuple(int)) ‚Äì Input image size. Default 224

  • patch_size (int | tuple(int)) ‚Äì Patch size. Default: 4

  • in_chans (int) ‚Äì Number of input image channels. Default: 3

  • num_classes (int) ‚Äì Number of classes for classification head. Default: 1000

  • embed_dim (int) ‚Äì Patch embedding dimension. Default: 96

  • depths (tuple(int)) ‚Äì Depth of each Swin Transformer layer.

  • num_heads (tuple(int)) ‚Äì Number of attention heads in different layers.

  • window_size (tuple(int)) ‚Äì Window size. Default: (7,7,7)

  • mlp_ratio (float) ‚Äì Ratio of mlp hidden dim to embedding dim. Default: 4

  • qkv_bias (bool) ‚Äì If True, add a learnable bias to query, key, value. Default: True

  • qk_scale (float) ‚Äì Override default qk scale of head_dim ** -0.5 if set. Default: None

  • drop_rate (float) ‚Äì Dropout rate. Default: 0

  • attn_drop_rate (float) ‚Äì Attention dropout rate. Default: 0

  • drop_path_rate (float) ‚Äì Stochastic depth rate. Default: 0.1

  • norm_layer (nn.Module) ‚Äì Normalization layer. Default: nn.LayerNorm.

  • ape (bool) ‚Äì If True, add absolute position embedding to the patch embedding. Default: False

  • patch_norm (bool) ‚Äì If True, add normalization after patch embedding. Default: True

  • use_checkpoint (bool) ‚Äì Whether to use checkpointing to save memory. Default: False

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

inflate_weights()[source]ÔÉÅ

Inflate the swin2d parameters to swin3d.

The differences between swin3d and swin2d mainly lie in an extra

axis. To utilize the pretrained parameters in 2d model,

the weight of swin2d models should be inflated to fit in the shapes of

the 3d counterpart.

Parameters:

logger (logging.Logger) ‚Äì

The logger used to print

debugging infomation.

class model.dim3.vtunet_utils.WindowAttention3D(dim, window_size, num_heads, qkv_bias=False, qk_scale=None, attn_drop=0.0, proj_drop=0.0)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: Module

Window based multi-head self attention (W-MSA) module with relative position bias.

It supports both of shifted and non-shifted window.

Parameters:

  • dim (int) ‚Äì Number of input channels.

  • window_size (tuple[int]) ‚Äì The temporal length, height and width of the window.

  • num_heads (int) ‚Äì Number of attention heads.

  • qkv_bias (bool, optional) ‚Äì If True, add a learnable bias to query, key, value. Default: True

  • qk_scale (float | None, optional) ‚Äì Override default qk scale of head_dim ** -0.5 if set

  • attn_drop (float, optional) ‚Äì Dropout ratio of attention weight. Default: 0.0

  • proj_drop (float, optional) ‚Äì Dropout ratio of output. Default: 0.0
